anise.note: Tiny seeds that remind of misplaced zeal—God desires mercy over meticulous measures (Matthew 23:23).

apple.note: Sweetness and shade in love’s poetry, evoking delight and refreshment (Song of Songs 2:5).

apples.note: Plural: sweetness and delight in love’s poetry (Song of Songs 2:5).

barley.note: Humble provision that feeds multitudes and honors God’s care for the poor (John 6:9).

beans.note: Simple strength for the journey and humility in God’s provision (Ezekiel 4:9).

bitter herbs.note: Taste of bondage remembered so deliverance will be cherished (Exodus 12:8).

black cumin.note: Seeds scattered with wisdom, gathered with care—God teaches even the farmer (Isaiah 28:25–27).

bread.note: Daily dependence and the word that truly sustains the soul (Matthew 4:4).

bread of affliction.note: Memory of haste and hardship that keeps freedom honest (Deuteronomy 16:3).

butter.note: Rich hospitality at covenant tables, a foretaste of fellowship (Genesis 18:8).

buttermilk.note: Refreshing sustenance in the tents of welcome and peace (Judges 5:25).

cake.note: Simple strength given in weakness, like bread by the hearth to the weary (1 Kings 19:6).

cakes.note: Offerings and celebrations made tangible in sweet portions (2 Samuel 6:19).

cakes of figs.note: Portable sweetness that revives the faint and honors the king (1 Samuel 30:12; 1 Chronicles 12:40).

cheese.note: Nourishment that strengthens servants of the king and pilgrims on the way (2 Samuel 17:29).

cinnamon.note: Fragrance of holiness, woven into set-apart anointing (Exodus 30:23).

coriander.note: Memory of heaven’s bread—manna seen in simple seeds (Exodus 16:31).

corn.note: Harvest in KJV sense of ‘grain,’ a sign of God’s increase (Psalm 65:13).

cucumber.note: Cravings of Egypt that tempt hearts to look back (Numbers 11:5).

cumin.note: Measured spice that warns against neglecting the weightier matters (Matthew 23:23).

curds.note: Richness shared at covenant tables, sign of pastoral abundance (Isaiah 7:15; 2 Samuel 17:29).

dates.note: Fruit of the palm and joy of oasis dwellers, whispering rest along the way (Judges 1:16).

deer.note: Provision from the wild, a picture of swiftness and God’s care for needs (Deuteronomy 14:5).

dill.note: Garden herb tied to tithes in some renderings—heart matters outweigh measures (Matthew 23:23).

dove’s dung.note: A desperate measure in a city under siege, sobering the heart (2 Kings 6:25).

eggs.note: Good gifts from a Father who delights to give the better thing (Luke 11:12).

fatted calf.note: Celebration of return and reconciliation in the Father’s house (Luke 15:23).

fig.note: Sign of peace and fruitfulness under God’s care (Micah 4:4).

fine flour.note: Best of the grain for offerings and daily bread, pointing to wholehearted devotion (Leviticus 2:1).

firstfruits.note: The earliest share offered in gratitude, trusting the harvest to come (Deuteronomy 26:10).

fish.note: Meal of miracles and mercy beside charcoal fires (John 21:9).

gall.note: Bitter mingling offered to the Sufferer, refused by love (Matthew 27:34).

garlic.note: Flavor of former bondage that should not allure the free (Numbers 11:5).

goat.note: Everyday meat and sacrificial symbol, reminding of cost and covering (Leviticus 4:27–28).

grain.note: Seed that dies to bear much life—pathway of the cross (John 12:24).

grape.note: Cluster of promise carried from a good land (Numbers 13:23).

honey.note: Sweetness that teaches wisdom and foretastes promised abundance (Proverbs 24:13).

honeycomb.note: Natural sweetness that strengthens and enlightens (1 Samuel 14:27).

kid.note: Tender portion served at feasts and signs of hospitality (Genesis 27:9).

lamb.note: Innocent offering and perfect Passover fulfilled in Christ (John 1:29).

leaven.note: Hidden influence that permeates—either kingdom life or corrupting pride (Matthew 13:33).

leeks.note: A taste of Egypt that tests the heart’s direction—backward or onward (Numbers 11:5).

lentils.note: A stew that warns against selling birthright for a moment’s hunger (Genesis 25:34).

locust.note: Food of the wilderness and sign of repentance’s simplicity (Mark 1:6).

manna.note: Bread from heaven that taught daily trust (Exodus 16:15).

meat.note: Solid food of maturity for those trained by practice (Hebrews 5:14).

melons.note: Cool relief in hot lands, yet a longing that can look the wrong way (Numbers 11:5).

milk.note: Nourishment for the newborn in faith, pure and life-giving (1 Peter 2:2).

milk and honey.note: Shorthand for promised plenty and God’s generous care (Exodus 3:8).

millet.note: One grain among many in humble loaves baked in lean times (Ezekiel 4:9).

mint.note: Measured tithes that call us back to justice, mercy, and faith (Matthew 23:23).

mustard.note: Small seed that grows shelter for many—greatness from little beginnings (Matthew 13:31–32).

new wine.note: Fresh joy of the vineyard, a sign of covenant blessing and renewal (Joel 2:24).

nuts.note: Choice gifts carried with humility and hope (Genesis 43:11).

oil.note: Anointing and gladness that overflow the cup (Psalm 23:5).

olive.note: Green branch and living tree—sign of peace and grafted grace (Romans 11:17).

onion.note: Sharp memory of Egypt’s kitchens that tests contentment (Numbers 11:5).

ox.note: Strength for the field and meat for the feast, crown of faithful labor (Deuteronomy 14:4; 25:4).

parched corn.note: Roasted grain shared at the edges of fields, kindness to the gleaner (Ruth 2:14).

partridges.note: Game sought and spared, a reminder that mercy is better than conquest (1 Samuel 26:20).

pistachio.note: A rare delight among gifts offered in prudence (Genesis 43:11).

pomegranate.note: Jewels of sweetness and beauty, echoing holiness on priestly robes (Exodus 28:33–34).

pottage.note: A bowl that can cost a legacy when appetite rules (Genesis 25:34).

pulse.note: Simple fare chosen for faithfulness and found enough (Daniel 1:12).

quail.note: Meat that satisfied craving yet warned against grumbling (Numbers 11:31–34).

raisins.note: Cakes that strengthen the weary and gladden the heart (1 Samuel 30:12).

roasted grain.note: Early produce offered in gratitude and eaten with gladness (Joshua 5:11).

roebuck.note: Graceful provision from the field among Israel’s clean foods (Deuteronomy 12:15).

salt.note: Preserving witness and covenant loyalty in daily life (Matthew 5:13).

sheep.note: Flocks that feed the family and furnish sacrifices—care that mirrors the Shepherd (2 Samuel 12:4).

showbread.note: Bread of the Presence—a continual witness to communion with God (Leviticus 24:5–9).

spelt.note: Old rendering for spelt, one of the grains that sustain in need (Isaiah 28:25, KJV).

strong drink.note: A potency to be handled with wisdom and restraint (Proverbs 31:4–7).

sycamore fruit.note: Humble work of a prophet who tended trees while tending truth (Amos 7:14).

unleavened bread.note: Bread of haste and purity, marking a break from bondage (Exodus 12:17).

venison.note: Savory dish of the hunt, cautionary when appetite steers the blessing (Genesis 27:3–4).

vine.note: Rooted life that bears fruit when abiding in the True Vine (John 15:5).

vinegar.note: Sour draught that met the Sufferer (John 19:29).

wheat.note: Good seed sown for a harvest of righteousness (Matthew 13:24).

wild gourds.note: Unknown pods in a prophet’s pot—bitterness healed by grace (2 Kings 4:39–41).

wild honey.note: Food of the wilderness that sweetens the path of repentance (Mark 1:6).

wine.note: Joy that gladdens and a sign pointing to better covenant feast (John 2:9–10).

wine with myrrh.note: Bitter draught offered to the Sufferer, refused to bear pain awake (Mark 15:23).
